text: But my covenant will I establish with Isaac, which Sarah shall bear unto thee at this set time in the next year.
text_kjv: But my covenant will I establish with Isaac, which Sarah shall bear unto thee at this set time in the next year.
text_niv: But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you by this time next year.”
text_esv: But I will establish my covenant with Isaac, whom Sarah shall bear to you at this time next year.”
text_nlt: But my covenant will be confirmed with Isaac, who will be born to you and Sarah about this time next year.”
text_msg: But I'll establish my covenant with Isaac whom Sarah will give you about this time next year."
text_nasb: 'But My covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this season next year.'
context: Genesis 17 unfolds within a patriarchal and tribal society where lineage and inheritance were paramount. The concept of a covenant, a binding agreement, was understood through the lens of ancient Near Eastern treaties and familial oaths. At the time, infertility was a source of immense shame and societal stigma, particularly for women. Sarah's barrenness, lasting well into her old age, presented a significant challenge to Abraham's hope for an heir and God's promise of descendants as numerous as the stars. The practice of surrogate motherhood, as evidenced by Abraham's union with Hagar, was a culturally accepted, albeit imperfect, solution to infertility issues. This chapter marks a pivotal moment in the Abrahamic covenant, moving beyond the earlier promises of land and offspring to a more specific and binding agreement marked by circumcision as its sign. God's interaction with Abraham reflects the power dynamics of the time, where a divine decree held absolute authority, yet it also reveals a personal relationship based on trust and obedience. The naming conventions were also significant; names held meaning and often reflected divine purpose or blessing. The emphasis on a specific time and a specific mother for Isaac highlights the divine intervention and miraculous nature of his birth within the prevailing social and cultural expectations.
meaning: Genesis 17:21 is a powerful declaration of God's sovereignty and faithfulness. It firmly establishes Isaac, not Ishmael, as the chosen heir through whom the covenant promises will be fulfilled. This verse clarifies God's selective grace, demonstrating that His blessings are not simply based on human effort or cultural practices (like Abraham's attempt to fulfill the promise through Hagar), but on His divine will and purpose. The phrase 'at this set time in the next year' underscores the miraculous nature of Isaac's birth, highlighting the divine timing and intervention in Sarah's previously barren state. Theologically, it points to God's power over the natural world and His ability to bring life where there was none. This verse also prefigures the concept of the 'seed' in Galatians 3:16, referring ultimately to Christ as the fulfillment of the Abrahamic covenant. By specifically naming Isaac as the covenant heir, God sets in motion the lineage through which salvation will ultimately come. The specificity of the covenant underscores the seriousness and permanence of God's promise. It reinforces the idea that God is not arbitrary or fickle; His word is reliable and His promises are sure, even when they seem impossible from a human perspective. The verse emphasizes the importance of faith and trust in God's timing, even when it contradicts our own understanding or expectations.
application: In our modern lives, Genesis 17:21 offers several powerful applications. First, it reminds us that God's timing is perfect, even when it doesn't align with our own desires or timelines. We often become impatient and try to force things to happen according to our own plans, much like Abraham did with Hagar. However, this verse encourages us to trust in God's sovereignty and to wait patiently for His perfect timing to unfold. Secondly, it speaks to the issue of comparison and jealousy. We may be tempted to compare ourselves to others who seem to be more blessed or successful, or to question why God hasn't answered our prayers in the way we expect. However, this verse reminds us that God has a specific plan for each of our lives, and that His blessings are tailored to our individual needs and purposes. Just as Isaac was chosen as the covenant heir, we are each chosen and called according to God's unique plan for us. Thirdly, it challenges us to examine our own hearts and to identify any areas where we are relying on our own efforts rather than trusting in God's grace. Are we trying to manipulate situations or control outcomes, or are we surrendering to God's will and allowing Him to work in our lives? This verse calls us to a deeper level of faith and dependence on God. Finally, it gives us hope in the face of seemingly impossible situations. Just as Sarah's barrenness seemed insurmountable, we may face challenges that appear overwhelming. However, this verse reminds us that God is able to do exceedingly abundantly above all that we ask or think (Ephesians 3:20). We should anchor our hope in God's power and faithfulness, knowing that He is able to bring life out of death and to fulfill His promises, even when it seems impossible.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your faithfulness and your enduring promises. Forgive me for the times when I have doubted your timing or tried to take matters into my own hands. Help me to trust in your sovereignty and to wait patiently for your perfect plan to unfold in my life. Grant me the grace to surrender my will to yours and to rely on your strength in the face of challenges. Help me to recognize and resist the temptation to compare myself to others, and to instead focus on your unique calling for my life. Fill me with hope and confidence in your ability to do the impossible. I trust in you, Lord, and I commit myself to your will. Amen.

faqs.answer: Ishmael was born of Hagar, Sarah's handmaid, representing a human attempt to fulfill God's promise. Isaac's birth was a miracle, born of the promised mother, Sarah, signifying God's supernatural intervention and choice. This highlights that covenant blessings are not solely determined by lineage but by God's sovereign will.
faqs.question: Q1: Why was Isaac chosen over Ishmael when Ishmael was Abraham's firstborn son?

faqs.answer: 'At this set time' emphasizes the precision and reliability of God's timing. It demonstrates that God is not haphazard but works according to His predetermined plan. It underscores that God's promises are sure and will be fulfilled at the exact moment He has ordained.
faqs.question: Q2: What does 'at this set time' signify in relation to God's promises?

faqs.answer: This verse reflects the concept of grace because Isaac's birth was a result of God's unmerited favor towards Abraham and Sarah. Sarah was beyond childbearing age, yet God intervened. This showcases that blessings are given not through works, but through God's gracious initiative.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the New Testament concept of grace?

faqs.answer: This verse demonstrates God's consistency by reaffirming the covenant originally promised to Abraham. Even when Abraham faltered, God remained steadfast in His commitment, ensuring the promise was fulfilled through the chosen heir, Isaac. God's character is unwavering.
faqs.question: Q4: What does this verse teach us about God's consistency?

faqs.answer: The specific mention of Sarah is crucial. It emphasizes the miraculous nature of Isaac's birth and ensures there's no ambiguity about the lineage. It connects the covenant promise to Sarah's womb, solidifying her role in God's plan and the legitimacy of Isaac's inheritance.
